currentLaws: Current Laws: California passed a mandate in 1990 which was updated in 2019. (California Insurance Code Section 10119.6, California Health and Safety Code Section 1374.551)

billsInProgress.title: AB 350
billsInProgress.description: Healthcare coverage; fluoride treatments
billsInProgress.status: Introduced in January 2025, currently in Committee on Health
details: The state would provide comprehensive clinical family planning services to people whose family income is at or below 200 percent of the federal poverty level
This includes education on fertility care options

colorado.name: Colorado
currentCoverage: Individual, group plans, and all large group (more than 100 employees) health benefit plans must provide coverage for the diagnosis of and treatment for infertility, and standard fertility preservation services.
Plans must cover three completed oocyte retrievals with unlimited embryo transfers, using single embryo transfers when recommended and medically appropriate.

Plans may not impose any: exclusions, limitations, or other restrictions on coverage of fertility medications that are different from those imposed on any other prescription medications covered under the health benefit plan; OR deductibles, copayments, coinsurance, benefit maximums, waiting periods, or other limitations on coverage for the diagnosis of and treatment for infertility and standard fertility preservation services that are different from those imposed on benefits for services covered under the health benefit plan that are not related to infertility.
exemptions: A religious employer may request, and the plan must grant an exclusion from the coverage requirement here if the coverage requirement conflicts with the religious organizations bona fide religious beliefs and practices.
If such employer obtains an exclusion, it must provide its employees reasonable and timely notice of the exclusion.
fertilityPreservation: The law requires health plans to cover 'standard fertility preservation services,' for a person who has a medical condition or is expected to undergo medication therapy, surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, or other medical treatment that is recognized by medical professionals to cause a risk of impairment to fertility.

billsInProgress.title: H.B. 5475
billsInProgress.description: AN ACT CONCERNING FERTILITY FRAUD BY PHYSICIANS To protect patients undergoing fertility treatments from physician misconduct.

billsInProgress.title: H.B. 6135
billsInProgress.description: AN ACT CONCERNING THE DEFINITION OF 'INFERTILITY' To revise the definition of 'infertility' for purposes of health insurance coverage under individual and group health insurance policies.

billsInProgress.title: H.B. 7022
billsInProgress.description: AN ACT PROMOTING EQUITY IN MEDICAID COVERAGE FOR FERTILITY HEALTH CARE.

takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Colorado!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to support bills in progress advancing fertility insurance coverage!
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates to effectively contact your legislators.

connecticut.name: Connecticut
currentCoverage: Individual and group health insurance policies must provide coverage for the medically necessary expenses of the diagnosis and treatment of infertility, including, but not limited to, ovulation induction, intrauterine insemination, IVF, uterine embryo lavage, embryo transfer, gamete intra-fallopian transfer, zygote intrafallopian transfer and low tubal ovum transfer.
NOT COVERED under the state Medicaid program.
Treatments or procedures must be performed at facilities that conform to the American Society of Reproductive Medicine and the Society of Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility Guidelines.
exemptions: Any insurance company, hospital service corporation, medical service corporation or health care center may issue to a religious employer an individual health insurance policy that excludes coverage for methods of diagnosis and treatment of infertility that are contrary to the religious employer's bona fide religious tenets.
fertilityPreservation: Standard fertility preservation services are covered

billsInProgress.title: HB 06588
billsInProgress.description: To allow the Commissioner of Public Health to revoke a physician's license if such physician is convicted of fertility fraud

billsInProgress.title: HB. 06568
billsInProgress.description: To address crisis pregnancies, promote informed consent and reduce the potential for infant abandonment while safeguarding the health of the birthing person and infant as an ethical approach to a birth in crisis.

billsInProgress.title: HB.05714
billsInProgress.description: To protect reproductive rights in cases where a woman decides to continue with a pregnancy.

takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Connecticut!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to support bills in progress advancing fertility insurance coverage!
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates to effectively contact your legislators.

delaware.name: Delaware
currentCoverage: Individual, group, and blanket health insurance policies must include coverage for fertility care services, including IVF, for individuals who suffer from infertility.
These benefits must be provided to covered individuals, including covered spouses and covered non-spouse dependents, to the same extent as other pregnancy-related benefits.
To qualify for coverage, all of the following requirements must be met:

A board-certified or board-eligible obstetrician-gynecologist, subspecialist in reproductive endocrinology, oncologist, urologist, or andrologist verifies that the covered individual is diagnosed with infertility or is at risk of iatrogenic infertility.

When the covered individual is diagnosed with infertility, the covered individual has not been able to obtain a successful pregnancy through reasonable effort with less costly infertility treatments covered by the policy, with the following exceptions:
No more than 3 treatment cycles of ovulation induction or intrauterine inseminations may be required before IVF is covered.
If IVF is medically necessary, no cycles of ovulation induction or intrauterine inseminations may be required before IVF is covered.
IVF procedure must be performed at a practice that conforms to American Society for Reproductive Medicine and American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists guidelines.
For IVF, retrievals are completed before the individual is 45 years old and transfers are completed before the individual is 50 years old.
exemptions: A religious employer may request, and the plan must grant an exclusion from the coverage requirement, if the coverage requirement conflicts with the religious organization's bona fide religious beliefs and practices.
If such employer obtains an exclusion, it must provide its employees reasonable and timely notice of the exclusion.
Employers who self-insure or who have fewer than 50 employees are exempt from the coverage requirements.
fertilityPreservation: The law requires coverage for standard fertility preservation services for individuals who must undergo medically necessary treatment that may cause iatrogenic infertility.
These benefits must be provided to covered individuals, including covered spouses and covered non-spouse dependents, to the same extent as other pregnancy-related benefits.
'Iatrogenic infertility' means an impairment of fertility due to surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, or other medical treatment.

billsInProgress.title: DE HB36
billsInProgress.description: This Act aligns Delaware's non-discrimination laws, including prohibiting discrimination in employment on the basis of a reproductive health decision.

billsInProgress.title: DE SB5
billsInProgress.description: An Act Proposing An Amendment To Article I Of The Delaware Constitution Relating To The Right To Reproductive Freedom.

takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Delaware!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to support bills in progress advancing fertility insurance coverage!
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates to effectively contact your legislators.

districtOfColumbia.name: District of Columbia
currentCoverage: All health insurers offering an individual, small group, or large group health benefit plan must provide coverage for the diagnosis and treatment of infertility, including the following:
Three rounds of IVF
Standard fertility preservation services.
At least 3 complete oocyte retrievals with unlimited embryo transfers from those oocyte retrievals or from any oocyte retrieval performed prior to January 1, 2025.

The medical costs related to an embryo transfer to be made from an enrollee to a third-party; except, that the enrollee's coverage shall not extend to any medical costs of the surrogate or gestational carrier after the embryo transfer procedure.
Infertility is determined by a licensed physician's findings based on a patient's medical, sexual, and reproductive history, age, physical findings, or diagnostic testing.
fertilityPreservation: An Insurer may not impose pre-existing condition exclusions or pre-existing condition waiting periods on coverage or use any prior diagnosis of or prior treatment for infertility as a basis for excluding, limiting, or otherwise restricting the availability of coverage for required benefits.
takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in District of Columbia!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to support bills advancing fertility insurance coverage!
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates to effectively contact your legislators.

currentLaws: No state mandate exists that would require insurance companies to offer coverage for fertility treatments.

billsInProgress.title: H0677
billsInProgress.description: Requires DMS under state group health insurance plan policies to provide coverage of medically necessary expenses relating to standard fertility preservation services; prohibits state group health insurance plans from requiring preauthorization for such services; authorizes maximum benefit provisions & cost-sharing requirements.

billsInProgress.title: H1499
billsInProgress.description: Provides that individuals have specified reproductive rights; prohibits local government from regulating individual's reproductive freedom.
billsInProgress.status: Referred to Health Professions & Programs Subcommittee

billsInProgress.title: S1380
billsInProgress.description: Creating the 'Protect Reproductive Options Act'; providing that every individual has a fundamental right to make autonomous decisions about the individual's own reproductive health; providing that individuals who become pregnant have a fundamental right to make certain decisions in exercise of such right, etc.

currentLaws: There are currently no laws mandating infertility treatment coverage, meaning insurance companies are not required to cover IVF or other fertility treatments.

hawaii.name: Hawaii
currentCoverage: Hawaii Revised Statute §432:1-604 and §431:10A-116.5
Individual and group health insurance plans that provide pregnancy-related benefits must also include a one-time-only benefit for all expenses arising from IVF procedures.
The coverage shall be provided to the same extent as maternity-related benefits.
The IVF procedures must be performed at medical facilities that conform to ACOG and ASRM guidelines.

billsInProgress.title: S.B. 23
billsInProgress.description: Ensures equal insurance coverage for in vitro fertilization (IVF) by removing discriminatory requirements.
details: Creates parity for same-sex couples, unmarried individuals, transgender persons, and opposite-sex couples affected by male infertility.
Reduces the required duration of infertility from five years to six months.
Includes cases needing medical intervention due to physiological or anatomical factors.

takeAction: Contact your representative and senator to champion fertility healthcare insurance coverage and protect against limitations to fertility healthcare.

idaho.name: Idaho

illinois.name: Illinois
currentCoverage: Illinois Compiled Statutes ch. 215 section 5/356m and section 5/356z.32
Group insurers and HMOs that provide pregnancy-related coverage must provide infertility treatment including IVF and related procedures.
Coverage includes up to 4 egg retrievals, with two additional covered if a live birth occurs (maximum 6 retrievals).
Procedures must follow ACOG and ASRM guidelines.
No discriminatory exclusions, limits, or benefit caps based on fertility treatment.
Policies must cover medically necessary standard fertility preservation services when medical treatment may cause infertility.
exemptions: Employers with fewer than 25 employees are exempt.
Religious employers are not required to cover infertility treatment.

billsInProgress.title: SB1259
billsInProgress.description: Amends the Illinois Insurance Code for expanded fertility coverage.
details: Requires coverage for standard fertility preservation services and follow-up services related to that coverage after June 1, 2026.

takeAction: Contact your representative and senator to champion fertility healthcare insurance coverage and protect against limitations to fertility healthcare.

louisiana.name: Louisiana
currentCoverage: Louisiana Revised Statute Section 22:1036
Health insurance policies cannot exclude coverage for diagnosis and treatment of a correctable medical condition otherwise covered by the policy solely because the condition results in infertility.
This law does not require coverage of fertility drugs, IVF, assisted reproductive techniques, or sterilization reversals.

Patients must meet specific requirements such as infertility duration or medical conditions like endometriosis.

Coverage includes all non-experimental infertility procedures (e.g., IVF, IUI, cryopreservation, ICSI, etc.).

ohio.name: Ohio
currentCoverage: Health insurance corporations must cover “basic health care services,” which include “infertility services” when medically necessary.
“Basic health care services” includes experimental procedures.
Medicaid-eligible individuals cannot be denied other Medicaid-covered medically necessary services on the basis of fertility or infertility.
exemptions: This does not apply to Multiple Employer Welfare Arrangements (MWEA) or Medicaid.
limitations: “Infertility” nor the standard for determining “medical necessity” with regard to infertility is not defined.

billsInProgress.title: HB136
billsInProgress.description: Prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity, or expression. Upholds religious exemptions under Ohio Civil Rights Law.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced; Referred to House Committee of Judiciary

billsInProgress.title: HB128
billsInProgress.description: Reproductive Care Act: Establishes protections for individuals seeking reproductive health care, ensuring privacy and legal protections.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced; Referred to House Committee on Health

Contact your legislators: Urge them to support bills advancing fertility insurance coverage! Find their info at Open States.
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates.

oklahoma.name: Oklahoma
currentCoverage: Health plans must cover standard fertility preservation services for individuals of reproductive age diagnosed with cancer if treatment may cause infertility.
Preauthorization is not required. Standard plan limitations such as deductibles and copays still apply.
exemptions: Religious employers may request an exemption if coverage conflicts with their beliefs. Must notify prospective enrollees.

billsInProgress.title: HB1117
billsInProgress.description: Provides legal protections for IVF providers, patients, and embryos.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced; Referred to House Committee on Public Health

billsInProgress.title: HB1201
billsInProgress.description: Creates tax credits for donations to pregnancy resource centers.

takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Oklahoma!

Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates.

oregon.name: Oregon
currentCoverage: Individual, small group, large group, MEWAs, and student plans must provide expanded access to free reproductive health services.
Oregon Medicaid (OHP) is not subject to RHEA but covers reproductive services without out-of-pocket costs.
Reproductive health services under private insurance must be free from copays or deductibles.
Coverage must not discriminate based on race, gender identity, disability, etc.
exemptions: Excludes short-term/limited plans, self-insured associations and employers (ERISA), Medicare, TRICARE, and others from RHEA requirements.

billsInProgress.title: SB535
billsInProgress.description: Requires coverage of specified fertility treatments. Includes exemptions for certain insurers.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced; Referred to Ways and Means

takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Oregon!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to support SB535 and other fertility legislation. Find their info at Open States.
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for templates and tips.

fertilityPreservation: Required for women aged 25–42 when treatment may cause iatrogenic infertility.
exemptions: Self-insured employers and Medicare/supplemental plans are exempt.

texas.name: Texas
currentCoverage: An issuer of a group health benefit plan that provides pregnancy-related benefits must offer coverage for in vitro fertilization (IVF) procedures.
IVF benefits must match the extent of other pregnancy-related benefits provided under the plan.
Coverage is required only if all the following conditions are met:
- The patient is covered under the group health plan.
- Fertilization is attempted only with the sperm of the patient’s spouse.
- The couple has a documented history of infertility for at least five continuous years OR the infertility is associated with:
• Endometriosis;
• Exposure in utero to diethylstilbestrol (DES);
• Blockage or surgical removal of fallopian tubes;
• Oligospermia.
- The patient has failed to achieve pregnancy with less costly applicable infertility treatments covered by the plan.
- The IVF procedures must be performed at a facility meeting ASRM standards.
fertilityPreservation: A health benefit plan must cover fertility preservation services for patients receiving medically necessary cancer treatment (e.g., surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation) that may impair fertility.
ASCO or ASRM must recognize the treatment as posing a risk to fertility.
Rejections of IVF coverage offers must be provided in writing.
exemptions: Insurers, HMOs, and self-insuring employers owned by or affiliated with a bona fide religious denomination that opposes IVF are not required to offer IVF coverage.

billsInProgress.title: HB 618
billsInProgress.description: Relates to health benefit plan coverage for IVF procedures for certain governmental employees and retirees.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced March 2025; Currently Considered in Calendars

billsInProgress.title: SB 833
billsInProgress.description: Defines conditions applicable to health benefit plan coverage of IVF procedures.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced February 2025; Referred to Senate Committee on Health & Human Services

takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Texas!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to support HB 618 and SB 833. Find their info at Open States.
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates to effectively contact your legislators.

utah.name: Utah
currentCoverage: For Medicaid patients and public employees under the Public Employees’ Health Plan: coverage includes IVF and genetic testing if the patient has cancer and requires treatments (surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy) that may cause sterility or iatrogenic infertility.
Public Employees’ Benefit and Insurance Plan provides a $4,000 benefit per qualified assisted reproductive technology (ART) cycle if:
- The patient is the one receiving ART services;
- The physician verifies the patient or spouse has a medically recognized infertility condition OR the patient attests to over a year of unsuccessful conception without contraception;
- Less costly treatments covered by the plan have failed;
- The ART procedure complies with the plan’s clinical policies and is performed at a facility meeting ASRM standards.
If the individual has already received an adoption indemnity benefit, they are ineligible for ART benefits.
fertilityPreservation: Medicaid patients can request approval for standard fertility preservation services if diagnosed with one of the following: cystic fibrosis, spinal muscular atrophy, Morquio syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, or sickle cell anemia.
takeAction: Support fertility healthcare in Utah!
Contact your legislators: Urge them to create and advance bills expanding fertility insurance coverage. Find their info at Open States.
Need help reaching out? Check out our Advocate for Yourself page for tips and templates to effectively contact your legislators.

vermont.name: Vermont
currentCoverage: Currently, there are no laws requiring health insurance providers to cover infertility treatment.

billsInProgress.title: HB 302
billsInProgress.description: Proposes requiring health insurance plans and Vermont Medicaid to provide coverage for fertility-related services.
billsInProgress.status: Introduced February 2025; Referred to House Committee on Health Care

westvirginia.name: West Virginia
currentCoverage: Mandate Year: 1977, 1995
Health maintenance organizations are required to provide basic health care services, including infertility services.

wisconsin.name: Wisconsin
currentCoverage: Mandate Year: 2018

The Wisconsin Department of Health Services shall distribute family planning and related preventative health services funds (including infertility services) to public entities, including state, county, and local health departments and clinics.
If funds remain, grants may be awarded to nonpublic entities like hospitals or federally qualified health centers that provide comprehensive primary and preventative care.
exemptions: An employee may refuse to offer family planning services due to personal beliefs. This refusal is protected from dismissal, suspension, demotion, or other employment discrimination.
